meanings.definition: To use superior strength or influence to intimidate someone, typically to force them to do something.
meanings.sent1: The big kid bullied the smaller child into giving him his lunch money.
meanings.sent2: She felt scared when she was bullied by her classmates at school.
meanings.sent3: The playground bully bullied the teacher into giving extra recess time.
meanings.sent4: His loud voice bullied its way through the crowded room.
meanings.sent5: The storm clouds bullied the sun out of the sky, casting a dark shadow over the town.

meanings.definition: To habitually seek to harm or intimidate someone perceived as vulnerable.
meanings.sent1: The mean girl bullied the new student every day after school.
meanings.sent2: He was constantly bullied by his older brother at home.
meanings.sent3: The mischievous cat bullied the dog by stealing its favorite toy.
meanings.sent4: The relentless wind bullied the fragile flower, bending it to its will.
meanings.sent5: The persistent rain bullied the river, causing it to overflow its banks.

meanings.definition: To act as a bully towards someone.
meanings.sent1: He would often bully his classmates during recess.
meanings.sent2: She didn't realize she was bullying her younger sibling until it was pointed out to her.
meanings.sent3: The bossy squirrel bullied the other animals in the forest to get the best acorns.
meanings.sent4: The aggressive waves bullied the shore, eroding it over time.
meanings.sent5: The loud thunder bullied the quiet night, startling all the animals in the forest.
